medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left tibial tubercle avulsion fracture. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Comminuted left tibial tubercle avulsion fracture with intraarticular extension. PROCEDURE: Open reduction and internal fixation of left tibia. ANESTHESIA: General. The patient received 10 ml of 0.5% Marcaine local anesthetic. TOURNIQUET TIME: 80 minutes. ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal. DRAINS: One JP drain was placed. COMPLICATIONS: No intraoperative complications or specimens. Hardware consisted of two 4-5 K-wires, One 6.5, 60 mm partially threaded cancellous screw and one 45, 60 mm partially threaded cortical screw and 2 washers. HISTORY AND PHYSICAL: The patient is a 14-year-old male who reported having knee pain for 1 month. Apparently while he was playing basketball on 12/22/2007 when he had gone up for a jump, he felt a pop in his knee. The patient was seen at an outside facility where he was splinted and subsequently referred to Children's for definitive care. Radiographs confirmed comminuted tibial tubercle avulsion fracture with patella alta. Surgery is recommended to the grandmother and subsequently to the father by phone. Surgery would consist of open reduction and internal fixation with subsequent need for later hardware removal. Risks of surgery include the risks of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes on sensation in most of the extremity, hardware failure, need for later hardware removal, failure to restore extensor mechanism tension, and need for postoperative rehab. All questions were answered, and father and grandmother agreed to the above plan. PROCEDURE: The patient was taken to the operating and placed supine on the operating table. General anesthesia was then administered. The patient was given Ancef preoperatively. A nonsterile tourniquet was placed on the upper aspect of the patient's left thigh. The patient's extremity was then prepped and draped in the standard surgical fashion. Midline incision was marked on the skin extending from the tibial tubercle proximally and extremities wrapped in Esmarch. Finally, the patient had tourniquet that turned in 75 mmHg. Esmarch was then removed. The incision was then made. The patient had significant tearing of the posterior retinaculum medially with proximal migration of the tibial tubercle which was located in the joint there was a significant comminution and intraarticular involvement. We were able to see the underside of the anterior horn of both medial and lateral meniscus. The intraarticular cartilage was restored using two 45 K-wires. Final position was checked via fluoroscopy and the corners were buried in the cartilage. There was a large free floating metaphyseal piece that included parts of proximal tibial physis. This was placed back in an anatomic location and fixed using a 45 cortical screw with a washer. The avulsed fragment with the patellar tendon was then fixed distally to this area using a 6.5, 60 mm cancellous screw with a washer. The cortical screw did not provide good compression and fixation at this distal fragment. Retinaculum was repaired using 0 Vicryl suture as best as possible. The hematoma was evacuated at the beginning of the case as well as the end. The knee was copiously irrigated with normal saline. The subcutaneous tissue was re-approximated using 2-0 Vicryl and the skin with 4-0 Monocryl. The wound was cleaned, dried, and dressed with Steri-Strips, Xeroform, and 4 x4s. Tourniquet was released at 80 minutes. JP drain was placed on the medium gutter. The extremity was then wrapped in Ace wrap from the proximal thigh down to the toes. The patient was then placed in a knee mobilizer. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Subsequently extubated and taken to the recovery in stable condition. POSTOP PLAN: The patient hospitalized overnight to decrease swelling and as well as manage his pain. He may weightbear as tolerated using knee mobilizer. Postoperative findings relayed to the grandmother. The patient will need subsequent hardware removal. The patient also was given local anesthetic at the end of the case.
layman:
**Pre‑operative diagnosis:**  
The left knee had a broken piece of bone at the tibial tubercle (the bump where the patellar tendon attaches).

**Post‑operative diagnosis:**  
The fracture was broken into several pieces and part of it went into the joint.

**Procedure:**  
The surgeon opened the knee and put the broken pieces back together and fixed them with metal wires and screws.

**Anesthesia:**  
The patient was put under general anesthesia (sleeping). A local anesthetic (Marcaine) was also given.

**Tourniquet time:**  
The tourniquet was on for 80 minutes.

**Estimated blood loss:**  
Very little.

**Drains:**  
One Jackson‑Pratt (JP) drain was placed.

**Complications:**  
None during the operation.

**Hardware used:**  
Two 4‑5 K‑wires, one 6.5 mm, 60 mm partially threaded cancellous screw, one 4.5 mm, 60 mm partially threaded cortical screw, and two washers.

---

### History and Physical

A 14‑year‑old boy had knee pain for one month. While playing basketball on 12/22/2007, he jumped and felt a “pop” in his knee. He was first treated at another hospital where a splint was applied, then sent to Children’s Hospital for definitive care. X‑rays showed a broken tibial tubercle with the patella higher than normal (patella alta). The doctors explained that surgery would fix the bone and later the hardware would need to be removed. They also explained the risks: anesthesia, infection, bleeding, numbness, hardware failure, need for later removal, possible loss of knee extension strength, and the need for rehab. The boy’s father and grandmother agreed to the plan.

---

### Operative Details

The boy was taken to the operating room, laid on his back, and given general anesthesia. He received a pre‑operative antibiotic (Ancef). A tourniquet was placed on the upper part of his left thigh. The leg was cleaned and draped. A midline incision was marked from the tibial tubercle upward. The leg was wrapped with an Esmarch bandage, the tourniquet was set to 75 mmHg, and the bandage was removed. The incision was made.

The surgeon found a large tear of the medial retinaculum and that the tibial tubercle had moved up into the joint. The bone was broken into many pieces and was inside the joint. The underside of both menisci was visible. The surgeon used two 4.5 K‑wires to hold the cartilage in place. Fluoroscopy confirmed the position. A large free bone fragment that included part of the growth plate was put back in place and fixed with a 4.5 mm cortical screw and washer. The fragment with the patellar tendon was then fixed to this area with a 6.5 mm, 60 mm cancellous screw and washer. The cortical screw did not compress the distal fragment well. The retinaculum was repaired with 0 Vicryl suture. Blood clots were removed at the start and end of the case. The knee was washed thoroughly with normal saline. The subcutaneous tissue was stitched with 2‑0 Vicryl and the skin with 4‑0 Monocryl. The wound was cleaned, dried, and covered with Steri‑Strips, Xeroform, and 4×4 gauze. The tourniquet was released after 80 minutes. A JP drain was placed. The leg was wrapped with Ace wrap from the thigh to the toes. A knee mobilizer was applied. The patient tolerated the surgery well, was taken off the breathing tube, and went to recovery in stable condition.

---

### Post‑operative Plan

The patient stayed overnight to reduce swelling and manage pain. He can bear weight as tolerated with the knee mobilizer. The grandmother was informed of the findings. The patient will need a later surgery to remove the hardware. Local anesthetic was given at the end of the operation.
